actions-list.actionItem: The Speaker announced that the House do now adjourn pursuant to clause 13 of Rule I. The next meeting is scheduled for 9:00 a.m. on March 14, 2025.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
Pursuant to clause 13 of Rule 1, the Chair announced the Speaker's designation of the period from Tuesday, March 11, 2025, to Sunday, March 23, 2025, as a "district work period".
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 214 — "Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 213 — "Electing Members to a certain standing committee of the House of Representatives."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1692 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enable secure and trustworthy technology through other transaction contracting authority, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 292
actions-list.actionItem: 132, 1 Present (Roll no. 71).

Considered as unfinished business. H.J. Res. 25 — "Providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Internal Revenue Service relating to "Gross Proceeds Reporting by Brokers That Regularly Provide Services Effectuating Digital Asset Sales"."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 217
actions-list.actionItem: 213 (Roll no. 70).

actions-list.header: On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 213
actions-list.actionItem: 216 (Roll no. 69).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1968 — "Making further continuing appropriations and other extensions for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 295
actions-list.actionItem: 127 (Roll no. 68).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1156 — "To amend the CARES Act to extend the statute of limitations for fraud under certain unemployment programs, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on passage of H.R. 1156, the motion to recommit H.R. 1968, on passage of H.R. 1968, if ordered, and on passage of H.J. Res. 25.

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 1968, the Chair put the question on the motion to recommit and announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Meng demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Ms. Meng moved to recommit to the Committee on Appropriations.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 1968.

Rule provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156 and H.R. 1968. The resolution provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156, and H.R. 1968 under a closed rule. Also, the resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each measure.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 211. H.R. 1968 — "Making further continuing appropriations and other extensions for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.J. Res. 25, the Chair put the question on passage of the joint resolution and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Davis (IL) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.J. Res. 25.

Rule provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156 and H.R. 1968. The resolution provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156, and H.R. 1968 under a closed rule. Also, the resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each measure.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 211. H.J. Res. 25 — "Providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Internal Revenue Service relating to "Gross Proceeds Reporting by Brokers That Regularly Provide Services Effectuating Digital Asset Sales"."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 1156, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Davis (IL) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 1156.

Rule provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156 and H.R. 1968. The resolution provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 25, H.R. 1156, and H.R. 1968 under a closed rule. Also, the resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each measure.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 211. H.R. 1156 — "To amend the CARES Act to extend the statute of limitations for fraud under certain unemployment programs, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 212 — "Returning Senate Joint Resolution 3 to the Senate."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 216
actions-list.actionItem: 214 (Roll no. 67).

actions-list.header: On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 216
actions-list.actionItem: 212 (Roll no. 66).
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 211.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 211 — "Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 25) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Internal Revenue Service relating to "Gross Proceeds Reporting by Brokers That Regularly Provide Services Effectuating Digital Asset Sales"; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1156) to amend the CARES Act to extend the statute of limitations for fraud under certain unemployment programs, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1968) making further continuing appropriations and other extensions for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. McGuire to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 11.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Monica De La Cruz to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
